author: Duccio Fumero
title: The Rugby Championship, match point Sudafrica contro gli All Blacks
text:
Per scoprire quote, pronostici, bonus, recensioni bookmaker su
scommesse sportive e molto altro su sport betting è possibile consultare la nostra nuova sezione dedicata alle scommesse online
Rugby
The Rugby Championship, match point Sudafrica contro gli All Blacks
Si disputa questo weekend il quarto turno della The Rugby Championship e per il Sudafrica c’è la chance di chiudere il discorso con due turni d’anticipo rispetto alla fine del torneo. Gli Springboks ospiteranno ancora la Nuova Zelanda, mentre nell’altro match di giornata l’Argentina ospiterà l’Australia, in una sfida per provare a restare in corsa.
Il Sudafrica è imbattuto e ha 14 punti in classifica, 8 in più rispetto agli All Blacks, con l’Argentina che segue a 9 punti e l’Australia ultima a 10 punti di distanza dal vertice. Una vittoria con bonus contro i neozelandesi e un successo senza bonus nell’altro match vorrebbe dire che gli Springboks potrebbero essere già matematicamente campioni.
Ma non sarà facile, perché la Nuova Zelanda vuole rialzare la testa e riaprire i giochi, ma per farlo Scott Robertson dovrà inventarsi qualcosa e trovare soluzioni per alzare il livello del rugby degli All Blacks, sin qui non all’altezza per vincere il torneo. I tuttineri sono spalle al muro e bisognerà vedere se questo potrà essere uno stimolo, o se bloccherà psicologicamente Barrett e compagni.
Tante incognite anche nell’altro match, dove l’Australia va a caccia della seconda vittoria consecutiva, mentre l’Argentina vorrà rialzare la testa dopo il ko casalingo dello scorso weekend. Con la consapevolezza che se gli All Blacks avranno battuto il Sudafrica chi vince rientra in corsa, mentre chi perde è virtualmente fuori. Se vincono gli Springboks, invece, vuol dire forse solo vincere per la gloria.

author: Shilpa Phadnis
title: US tech jobs pick up, green shoots for Indian IT - Times of India
text: In total, there were an estimated 438,000 active tech job postings in MarchBENGALURU: A revival of tech hiring in the US, indicating a recovery in demand, bodes well for Indian IT companies that have a significant presence in America. Tech companies in America added an estimated 6,000 workers last month, an analysis of US govt data by Computing Technology Industry Association showed.The presence of Indian IT companies in the US has grown with TCS employing 50,000 people, Infosys 35,000, HCL Tech 24,000, Wipro 20,000, and LTIMindtree 6,500. Together, these companies account for about 2% of the US tech industry workforce, according to an HDFC Securities report. The broad-based presence of the sector across various locations in the US may be advantageous for demand recovery.Job growth was driven by hiring in technology services, software development, and cloud infrastructure. US employers posted 191,000 new job openings for tech positions in March, an increase of 8,000 from the previous month and the highest volume since August 2023. In total, there were an estimated 438,000 active tech job postings in March. Software developers and IT support specialists saw the largest increases in openings between Feb & March. CompTIA's report noted that New York, Washington, Dallas, Chicago, Los Angeles, and San Francisco had the highest volumes of job postings in March.HDFC Securities analysts noted that tech employment in the US grew by 1.2% in 2023, with the workforce increasing by 117,000 to 9.6 million, which includes non-technical employees too. CompTIA forecasts a 3.1% increase (more than 300,000 net increase) in the US tech workforce for the 2024 calendar year.As bench strength is optimised with utilisation levels closer to the six-year average (yet below the 2022 peak), HDFC Securities expects hiring in the sector to resume in a couple of quarters, with growth continuing to be volume-led. Despite the significant layoffs in tech during the 2023 calendar year (estimated at 500,000), the US tech workforce added employees during the year. Since then, layoffs have moderated, and hiring activity is expected to recover, which has been correlated with demand and revenue growth.HDFC Securities stated, \"The last few quarters have seen a sequential dip in headcount which could reverse in the second half of 2025 fiscal. The upcoming Q4 results will reflect the growth divergence within companies, and we expect growth to bottom out and recover gradually in FY25.\"

author: Olimar Salazar Guevara
title: Abarrotadas las calles de Cumaná en respaldo a Nicolás Maduro
text:
Con alegría y fervor patrio el pueblo chavista del estado Sucre, salió nuevamente a marchar por las calles de Cumaná, para reiterar su apoyo rotundo y contundente a la Revolución Bolivariana.
La multitudinaria movilización partió desde la iglesia Virgen del Valle, recorrió la avenida Bermúdez y finalizó en la calle Ayacucho de la ciudad primogénita, donde el pueblo revolucionario una vez más, demostró su compromiso por seguir consolidando la construcción del socialismo.
La marcha estuvo encabezada por el gobernador del estado Sucre, Gilberto Pinto; el enlace estadal de la Dirección Nacional del Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (Psuv), Jesús Faría, y el alcalde de Cumaná, Luis Sifontes.
“El poder está en el pueblo y el pueblo está en la calle, para demostrarle al mundo que aquí hay hombres y mujeres conscientes y leales, que el próximo 28 de julio saldrá a defender a la Revolución Bolivariana”, exaltó el enlace estadal del Psuv, Jesús Faría.
El también diputado a la Asamblea Nacional (AN) instó a las estructuras comunales a seguir organizando y fortaleciendo la gran maquinaria electoral del 1×10, en aras de asegurar la reelección del Ejecutivo Nacional.
Por su parte, el gobernador Gilberto Pinto afirmó que seguirán movilizados para alzar la voz en rechazo a las agresiones y las medidas coercitivas unilaterales que la oposición venezolana ha promovido en contra del país, las cuales apuntó han ocasionado inestabilidad en el poder adquisitivo de la población.
“Nosotros seguiremos movilizados en contra de esa mal llamada oposición, que se ha dedicado a recorrer el mundo para pedir y exigir sanciones, que hoy en día, han afectado la economía de nuestra patria. Pero a ellos, este pueblo les envía un mensaje. Las persecuciones, el bloqueo y el fascismo tienen un candidato, pero la patria buena, del futuro, de la paz y el progreso también tienen un candidato y se llama Nicolás Maduro”, resaltó el gobernador Gilberto Pinto.
A su vez, el alcalde de Cumaná, Luis Sifontes, felicitó la “extraordinaria” manifestación de fuerza que demuestra la lealtad absoluta e inquebrantable del pueblo sucrense.
“Este es el amor de un pueblo que nuevamente, hoy, echó a andar en las calles de la Cumaná rebelde y victoriosa para demostrar su lealtad a este proceso revolucionario, que es el único en el mundo que garantiza la prosperidad de la patria. Esta misma lealtad se refleja en Valdez, Mariño, Cajigal, Libertador, en Benítez y en el resto de los municipios que conforman esta región de mi amada Venezuela”, puntualizó Sifontes.

author: Berny Torre
title: Police figures show ‘deeply worrying’ rise in religious hate crimes after October 7 | Morning Star
text:
Police figures show ‘deeply worrying’ rise in religious hate crimes after October 7 A Metropolitan police officer outside royal court of justice × This is the last article you can read this month You can read more article this month You can read more articles this month Sorry your limit is up for this month Reset on:
Please help support the Morning Star by subscribing here RELIGIOUS hate crimes across Britain have soared in the wake of the Hamas-Israel conflict, “deeply worrying” police figures reveal today.
Freedom of information requests to forces showed a sharp rise in the number of reported anti-semitic and Islamophobic offences since the Hamas attack in Israel on October 7 and the Israeli invasion of Gaza, which has killed more than 21,000 people.
Based on responses from 31 forces across the UK, the data pointed to a jump in anti-semitic offences recorded by forces mostly concentrated in cities or across built-up areas, while the pattern for Islamophobic offences was more varied.
The British Transport Police had one of the largest increases, recording 87 anti-semitic offences in the month after October 7, up from eight in the same period in 2022 and 11 in 2021, as well as a jump in Islamophobic offences with 22 this year, compared to two in 2022 and eight in 2021.
It comes amid criticism from anti-racist and anti-fascist campaigners against the government for sowing division in communities and branding pro-Palestine protests “hate marches.”
Stand up to Racism co-convener Sabby Dhalu said: “The rise in anti-semitic and Islamophobic hate crimes is deeply worrying.
“Wars in the Middle East should not lead to division and hatred in Britain.
“All of us have a duty to root out anti-semitism, Islamophobia and all forms of racism and hatred.”
Islamophobia monitoring organisation Tell Mama said that “levels of anti-Muslim hatred and discrimination are deeply worrying, impacting trust in authorities and their sense of identity and belonging.”
The Muslim Council of Britain added: “Despite the extremely low reporting rate from Muslim communities, the huge increase in Islamophobic hate crimes recorded with the police reflects what we are seeing from third-party reporting groups.
“The government’s laissez-faire attitude to Islamophobia contrasts strongly with its no-tolerance approach to anti-semitism.
“We are hopeful this will now change.”
The Jewish charity the Community Security Trust described the figures as “shocking” and said they made clear “the extent of the unacceptable rise in anti-Jewish hatred” across the country since October 7.
The Home Office said: “There is no place for hate in our society and we condemn the recent rise in reported anti-semitic and anti-Muslim hatred.”

author: BusinessDay
title: Police foil kidnapping operation, rescue victim after gun battle - Businessday NG
text: The Nigeria Police Force has thwarted a kidnapping operation and rescued the victim amidst a tense exchange of gunfire. According to Mansir Hassan, the Police Public Relations Officer, Kaduna Police Command, the gunmen opened fire during the rescue of Segun Akinyemi, an Abuja resident, on Thursday. “The rescue mission unfolded on January 18, 2024, after the Kawo Divisional Headquarters in Kaduna received a distress call regarding a kidnapping incident originating from Abuja. “Operatives swiftly responded to the alert, discovering that the kidnappers and their victim were passing through Kaduna. In the early hours, at approximately 0010, the police intercepted a grey Toyota Hilux van with registration number Abuja RBC 90 DC. The vehicle, suspected to be transporting the kidnappers and their victims, was blocked by the authorities. “A tense exchange ensued when one of the kidnappers fired at the police officers in an attempt to escape. “The officers retaliated, resulting in a gun duel. Fortunately, Segun Akinyemi, residing at block 10, flat 2 FCDA quarters Area 3 Garki, Abuja, was successfully rescued during the confrontation,” Hassan stated. He further stated that the arrest of one of the kidnappers, identified as Chinaza Philip, 28-year-old from Life Camp Abuja, marks a significant development in the ongoing investigation. Presently, authorities are actively pursuing the three remaining suspects who evaded capture. The recovered items from the kidnappers include the victim’s vehicle, two Retay G17 model pistols, one Beretta pistol, ten 9mm P.A.K ammunition, and five 9mm special ammunition. Hassan disclosed that findings indicate that Akinyemi was abducted on January 17, 2024, as he departed from his residence. The police thwarted the kidnappers’ journey to Kano in a commendable interception. Commending the operatives for their courage, A.D Ali, Commissioner of Police for Kaduna State, encouraged persistent efforts to pursue criminal elements within the state. He further urged the public to utilize security agencies’ hotlines for swift responses to distress calls.

author: Noémie Duriez
title: Le bon plan de la semaine : des paniers (bien remplis) de légumes et fruits locaux pour moins de 35€ à Esnes
text:
Le bon plan de la semaine : des paniers (bien remplis) de légumes et fruits locaux pour moins de 35€ à Esnes
Chaque semaine, le Chalet d’Esnes propose des paniers de fruits et de légumes de leur production locale. Deux types de paniers pour deux budgets différents sont proposés : 20€ ou 35€. Asperges, salades, courges, pommes de terre ou encore des fraises lorsque c’est de saison, les propositions sont variées.
Réservez votre panier
C’est une idée lancée par Aurélie Derieux avant « l’épidémie de coronavirus pour permettre aux gens de manger des produits locaux ». Depuis, ce concept en a emballé plus d’un. Pour cela, elle concocte toutes les semaines des paniers « avec des fruits et des légumes de saison et qui sont modifiés. Les paniers peuvent être agrémentés selon les préférences du client, on s’adapte ».
Postés chaque dimanche soir sur
la page Facebook du point de vente, les paniers sont vus par « les clients qui peuvent les réserver, par la suite au téléphone » poursuit-elle.
Avec trois points de dépôt, la productrice livre ses paniers dans différentes boulangeries : « Martin Martine de Cambrai, à Beaurevoir dans l’Aisne ainsi qu’à Villers-Outréaux » pour ceux ayant commandé. Des paniers sont également disponibles à leur point de vente à Esnes.Ouvert du lundi au jeudi de 13h30 à 19h30. Le vendredi et le samedi de 10h00 à 19h30. Téléphone : 06 71 92 45 05. Le Chalet d’Esnes est situé au 17 rue de Cambrai 59127 à Esnes.

author: Lauren Smith
title: Bobby Offers Chris Tomlin Raging Idiots Song “Jesus Knows” | The Bobby Bones Show
text:
Chris Tomlin stopped by The Bobby Bones Show on Good Friday, to talk about his new book and more!
Tomlin’s new book, How Great Is Our God: Living a Worship Led Life In A Me Driven World focuses on the society we live in. He noticed that everything is “me” driven and wanted this book to be a reminder that God is the center of all things. When he started writing it, he found that it’s easy to point fingers at the next generation and say everyone is so self-absorbed, but when he did more research, it hit him that this is the issue of mankind. Everyone deals with how we get our eyes so off ourselves that life does not just revolve around us. He chose the book title because it was one of his biggest songs and he feels like it represents the heart of the book.
Tonight, Tomlin’s Good Friday concert is at Bridgestone Arena in Nashville, Tennessee. It will feature performances from Tomlin, Willie Robertson, Anne Wilson, Kari Jobe and will have a few surprise guests. All proceeds from the evening go to help provide support and assistance for children in foster care. It’s his 8th year doing the show in Nashville, and it started when he was living in Texas. It’s a night of gathering from all different churches in the middle Tennessee area and he loves having everyone together to remember God and his faith.
If someone asked him to sign a bible, back in the day he would say no because it felt weird. Now, he agrees to it and will point them to one of his favorite scriptures and encourage them to read it. Tomlin wants people to know he is normal and does not think he is better than anyone else. He does get a lot of people pouring out their hearts to him and wanting advice on what to do. He tries to give the best advice he can because he takes great responsibility for what he does. He realizes he’s different than just an artist who plays music, there is a weight to it, and he knows when he walks on stage that he is helping people with their Faith and connecting with God.
Tomlin got into music when he was 9 years old and sick with mono. He had to spend the whole summer at home and not play baseball, which he was devastated about. His father owned a pharmacy that had a music store connected to it and his dad loved country music so since he was home sick all summer, he taught him how to play guitar. Every morning before his dad left for work, he would write out chords for him to learn. He’d practice all day long and play for him when he’d get home. It changed the trajectory of his life and started it all for him he shared.
Bobby Bones and The Raging Idiots offered him their Christian song “ Jesus Knows ” which is a parody song about Jesus knowing when you do things like run a red light or wear clothes with the tag still on it to return later. Tomlin loved the idea of the song.
His new album, Live from Good Friday, is available now!

author: Simon Evans
title: USL will bring pro/rel to America
text: The United Soccer League says it plans to become the first professional sports league in the USA to adopt promotion and relegation.

author: time news
title: ChatGPT’s false empathy
text:
Anthropomorphism is the tendency to attribute human characteristics to non-human entities, such as machines ‌or animals. In​ the case of chatbots like ChatGPT, Gemini or Copilot, this phenomenon occurs when they imitate ‍human language to communicate with us.‌ They not only use⁤ understandable and familiar words and phrases, but also adopt people’s‌ communication patterns. They are ​thus‍ able to maintain contextual and coherent conversations and can even show ‌humor and empathy.

This⁢ design of language⁤ in⁤ machines seeks ‌to make interacting with them natural, seamless, and accessible. This makes⁤ it easy to‍ use in a variety of applications, from customer service to education and entertainment.

One ​of the most distinctive characteristics of human language is subjectivity, which manifests itself in the choice of emotionally charged words and the expression ⁢of personal opinions. It also appears in the evaluation‍ of events and‌ the⁣ use ​of contextual ⁢and cultural elements.

 
 Him chatbots ELIZA, released ⁢in 1966, already simulated ⁤human behavior,‌ adopting​ the role of a psychologist in conversation with the user.



 The impact of the first person 
When a machine pretends to be human in communication, important ethical and⁢ psychological implications arise. These interactions can influence how we‍ perceive and relate to technology.

A typical feature of human subjectivity in language is the use of⁣ personal pronouns. First ​person (like “I” and ⁢“we”) allows you to express your thoughts and experiences. The second person (like “you” and “you”) engages the‍ interlocutor, building a relationship between‍ the participants in the conversation. In human interaction, this is called⁤ intersubjectivity.

 
 
User: “How do you prioritize which items to keep, donate, or throw away during the organizing process?”

 
 
 Chatbots :⁤ “Great question! ⁣Organizing​ your​ belongings ⁣can be complicated, but with a clear ‍strategy you can make easier decisions. Here are some ideas for prioritizing what ⁢to keep, donate or ​throw away.”

 
 
Him chatbots implicitly uses the first person. Even if the “I” does not appear, the sender assumes a position of⁤ advisor or guide.​ For example, in the sentence “Here I present some ideas,” the verb “present” is ‍in ‍the first person.

This‌ suggests that the chatbots takes on the role of the​ one who provides help.‍ The user ⁤therefore perceives personal treatment, even if the “I” is not explicitly used. Additionally, the use of “present” reinforces the image of the sender as someone offering something valuable.

 Use of the second⁤ person 
“You” (and forms such as “you” and “your”) are used to address ⁣you⁢ directly. This is found in ​several parts of the text, such as in the sentences: “Organize THE ⁤ your possessions can be overwhelming” and “with a‌ clear strategy, Candies make decisions easier.”

When I talk to him personally, he chatbots Try to make the reader​ feel like an active part ‌of the advice. This ⁣type‌ of language is common in⁤ texts ⁣that seek to directly engage the other.

Other elements ​in the interaction, such as “Great ‍question!”, not only positively⁤ evaluate⁣ the user’s⁤ question ⁣but also encourage participation. Similarly, expressions such ⁣as “can be overwhelming” suggest a shared experience, creating an illusion of empathy by acknowledging the user’s possible emotions.

 Effects of artificial empathy 
The use of the first person by the chatbots ​ it simulates consciousness and tries to create an illusion of empathy. By adopting‍ a helping position and‌ using the second person, you involve the user and reinforce the perception of closeness. This combination creates a conversation that feels more human and practical, suited to‌ counseling, even if the empathy comes from‍ an algorithm, not real understanding.

Getting used to interacting with non-conscious entities that simulate identity and personality can have long-term effects. These interactions can influence aspects of our personal, ‌social and cultural lives.

As these ⁣technologies improve, distinguishing between a ⁣conversation with a person ​and one with ‌an artificial intelligence may become ‍difficult.

This blurring of the boundaries between the human and the artificial influences⁣ how we understand authenticity,​ empathy, and conscious presence in communication. We could even‌ treat artificial intelligences as if they were conscious beings, generating confusion about their real⁢ capabilities.

 It is uncomfortable to talk to humans 
Interactions with machines can‌ also change our expectations of ‍human relationships. As we get used to quick, seamless, conflict-free interactions,⁣ we may feel more frustrated ​in our relationships with people.

Human relationships are marked by emotions, misunderstandings and complexity. This, ⁣in the long term, could decrease our patience and ability to manage conflicts and accept natural imperfections in

Furthermore, prolonged exposure to entities​ that simulate‌ humanity raises‌ ethical and philosophical⁤ dilemmas.‍ By ascribing to them human⁢ qualities, such as the ability to feel or have intentions, we might begin to question the ⁣value of conscious life in the face of a perfect simulation. This could open up debates about robot rights and the value of human ‌consciousness.

Interacting with non-conscious ⁢entities that‌ mimic human identity can alter our ⁤perception ​of communication, relationships, and identity. While these technologies ‌offer efficiency benefits, it is crucial to be aware of their limitations and possible impacts on the way we interact, both with machines and with each ⁢other.



 
 Interview between Time.news Editor and AI Communication Expert

 Editor: Welcome to Time.news, where we delve into the most pressing topics of our time. Today, we have⁣ Dr. Maya Thompson, a renowned expert in AI communication and anthropomorphism. Dr. Thompson, thank you for ⁣joining us!

 Dr. Thompson: Thank you⁤ for having me! It’s a pleasure to discuss such​ a fascinating topic.

 Editor: Let’s dive right in. Anthropomorphism is a key concept in AI communication, especially ⁢with chatbots like ChatGPT and Gemini. Can you explain how this tendency shapes our interactions with these technologies?‍

 Dr. Thompson: Absolutely! Anthropomorphism refers to attributing human characteristics⁢ to non-human entities. In the context of chatbots, they leverage this tendency ‍by mimicking human language and‌ communication patterns. This human-like approach⁤ helps make interactions feel more natural and accessible, which is essential for their various applications, from customer service to education and entertainment.

 Editor: That’s interesting! ⁤You mentioned ⁤the⁣ use of language—the emotionally charged ⁤words and personal opinions. How does ⁣this‍ subjectivity impact our perception‌ of chatbots?

 Dr. Thompson: Human language is incredibly subjective, which means ⁤it’s colored by emotions and personal experiences. When ⁢chatbots use phrases that resonate on a personal level, it creates a connection. For instance, using phrases like “Great ‌question!” not⁣ only‍ acknowledges the user’s input but also fosters engagement. This ability to simulate an understanding of emotions can ⁢lead users to feel more connected to the technology, even if it’s an algorithm responding.

 Editor: It⁤ sounds like chatbots are not just providing information; they’re creating a relational experience. Can you explain the significance of first-person and second-person language in this‍ context?

 Dr. Thompson: Certainly! The use of first-person language, such as “I present” or similar‍ constructs, positions the chatbot as a guide or advisor. It suggests a personal touch, even when the “I” may not be explicitly stated. On the flip side, when ‍chatbots use second-person language—addressing users directly—it helps engage them as‌ active participants in the conversation. This combination ⁣creates a conversational dynamic that feels⁢ intimate and personalized.

 Editor: ‌So, there’s an illusion of empathy created through language. What are the ethical implications of this?

 Dr. ⁤Thompson: The ethical implications are substantial. When chatbots simulate empathy, users may develop emotional attachments ‌or rely on them for support without realizing they lack true understanding or consciousness. Over‍ time, this can affect how individuals relate to technology and even‍ to each other. It’s crucial for users to understand‍ that, while these interactions​ may feel personal, they’re ⁣ultimately driven by algorithms.

 Editor: That raises an important point. As these technologies evolve, do you think there are long-term effects on our social and cultural dynamics?

 Dr. ⁣Thompson: Definitely. As ⁤interacting with these anthropomorphized entities becomes normal, we may start to ‍blur the lines between machine and human interactions in our daily lives. This could influence our expectations of human relationships, communication, and ‍even societal norms. We might become desensitized​ to the lack of authentic emotional exchange, which poses challenges in how we⁣ engage with one another.

 Editor: Insightful! What advice would you give to ‍users to navigate these interactions healthily?

 Dr. Thompson: I’d say, approach chatbots with awareness. Understand that while they may provide valuable information and mimic ⁤empathy,‍ they do not possess consciousness ‍or genuine emotions. Prioritize real⁤ human connections, and use AI tools as aids rather than replacements for interpersonal relationships. Balance is key.

 Editor: Thank you, Dr. Thompson, for shedding light on this complex interplay between humanity and technology.‍ It’s clear that as chatbots become more intelligent and relatable, we need to remain thoughtful about our interactions with them.

 Dr. Thompson: Thank you⁤ for having me! It’s been⁤ a pleasure discussing these vital issues.

 Editor: And thank you to our audience for tuning in. Stay curious, and continue to explore the fascinating world of AI at Time.news.
